io.github.utk003.util.misc

Class Verifier

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.github.utk003.util.misc.Verifier

  • public class Verifier
extends Object
    An abstract utility class for verification functions.

    This class provides these methods:

    • The fail methods, which always throw a VerificationException.
    • The requireTrue methods, which throw a VerificationException if and only if the given boolean expression evaluates to false.
    • The requireFalse methods, which throw a VerificationException if and only if the given boolean expression evaluates to true.
    • The requireNull methods, which throw a VerificationException if and only if the given object expression is not null.
    • The requireNotNull methods, which throw a VerificationException if and only if the given object expression is null.
    • The requireEqual methods, which throw a VerificationException if and only if the given objects or primitives do not match.
    • The requireNotEqual methods, which throw a VerificationException if and only if the given objects or primitives do match.
    Since:
    1.2.0
    Version:
    February 25, 2021
    Author:
    Utkarsh Priyam (utk003)

      • requireNotNull

        @Contract(value="null -> fail")
 @NotNull
public static <T> T requireNotNull(@Nullable
                                                                             T obj)
        Throws an VerificationException (with no message) if and only if the given object is not not-null (or, equivalently, is null).

        This method is identical to Objects.requireNonNull(Object).

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the object to check
        Parameters:
        obj - The type-T argument to check
        Returns:
        The argument (guaranteed to be not null)
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the Object argument is null
        See Also:
        Objects.requireNonNull(Object)

      • requireNotNull

        @Contract(value="null,_ -> fail")
 @NotNull
public static <T> T requireNotNull(@Nullable
                                                                               T obj,
                                                                               String message)
        Throws an VerificationException (with the specified message) if and only if the given object is not not-null (or, equivalently, is null).

        This method is identical to Objects.requireNonNull(Object, String).

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the object to check
        Parameters:
        obj - The type-T argument to check
        message - The message for the exception
        Returns:
        The argument (guaranteed to be not null)
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the Object argument is null
        See Also:
        Objects.requireNonNull(Object, String)

      • requireEqual

        public static void requireEqual(Object arg1,
                                Object arg2)
        Throws an VerificationException (with no message) if and only if the two object arguments are not equal.

        This verification method uses Objects.equals(Object, Object) to check for equality. For memory-based equality (using ==), use requireExactlyEqual(Object, Object) instead.

        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are not equal

      • requireEqual

        public static void requireEqual(Object arg1,
                                Object arg2,
                                String message)
        Throws an VerificationException (with the specified message) if and only if the two object arguments are not equal.

        This verification method uses Objects.equals(Object, Object) to check for equality. For memory-based equality (using ==), use requireExactlyEqual(Object, Object, String) instead.

        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        message - The message for the exception
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are not equal

      • requireNotEqual

        public static void requireNotEqual(Object arg1,
                                   Object arg2)
        Throws an VerificationException (with no message) if and only if the two object arguments are equal.

        This verification method uses Objects.equals(Object, Object) to check for equality. For memory-based equality (using ==), use requireNotExactlyEqual(Object, Object) instead.

        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are equal

      • requireNotEqual

        public static void requireNotEqual(Object arg1,
                                   Object arg2,
                                   String message)
        Throws an VerificationException (with the specified message) if and only if the two object arguments are equal.

        This verification method uses Objects.equals(Object, Object) to check for equality. For memory-based equality (using ==), use requireNotExactlyEqual(Object, Object, String) instead.

        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        message - The message for the exception
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are equal

      • requireExactlyEqual

        public static <T> T requireExactlyEqual(T arg1,
                                        T arg2)
        Throws an VerificationException (with no message) if and only if the two object arguments are not equal, and returns the common value otherwise.

        This verification method uses == to check for equality. For object-based equality verification (using Objects.equals(Object, Object)), use requireEqual(Object, Object) instead.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the object to check
        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        Returns:
        The common value of the two arguments
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are not equal

      • requireExactlyEqual

        public static <T> T requireExactlyEqual(T arg1,
                                        T arg2,
                                        String message)
        Throws an VerificationException (with the specified message) if and only if the two object arguments are not equal, and returns the common value otherwise.

        This verification method uses == to check for equality. For object-based equality verification (using Objects.equals(Object, Object)), use requireEqual(Object, Object, String) instead.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the object to check
        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        message - The message for the exception
        Returns:
        The common value of the two arguments
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are not equal

      • requireNotExactlyEqual

        public static void requireNotExactlyEqual(Object arg1,
                                          Object arg2)
        Throws an VerificationException (with no message) if and only if the two object arguments are equal.

        This verification method uses == to check for equality. For object-based equality verification (using Objects.equals(Object, Object)), use requireNotEqual(Object, Object) instead.

        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are equal

      • requireNotExactlyEqual

        public static void requireNotExactlyEqual(Object arg1,
                                          Object arg2,
                                          String message)
        Throws an VerificationException (with the specified message) if and only if the two object arguments are equal.

        This verification method uses == to check for equality. For object-based equality verification (using Objects.equals(Object, Object)), use requireNotEqual(Object, Object, String) instead.

        Parameters:
        arg1 - The first argument to check
        arg2 - The second argument to check
        message - The message for the exception
        Throws:
        VerificationException - If the two arguments are equal
